study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the CYP3A inhibitory potential of grapefruit juice and other herbal supplements to assess their drug interaction potential.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice showed >80% CYP3A inhibition in cryopreserved human intestinal mucosa (CHIM), indicating a high potential for pharmacokinetic interactions with orally administered CYP3A substrate drugs. The results were consistent with known drug interaction risks associated with grapefruit juice.
population_specificity: In vitro models (cryopreserved human intestinal mucosa and enterocytes).
effective_dosage: Estimated lumen concentration based on manufacturers' recommended dosage dissolved in 200 ml of culture medium.
interactions: Potential interactions with orally administered drugs that are CYP3A substrates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the electrical conductivity and heating rate of grapefruit juice under ohmic heating and vacuum conditions, comparing it to lemon juice.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice had 20% lower electrical conductivity than lemon juice under the same conditions, and its heating rate reduction ranged from 19% to 32%. Vacuum pressure significantly affected the pH of both juices.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on juices)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the wound healing efficacy and antibacterial properties of a hydrogel film incorporating grapefruit seed extract (GSE) in a carrageenan-based matrix.
results_summary: The hydrogel film (Carr/GSE/SNP) demonstrated strong antibacterial activity against Staphylococcus epidermis and Escherichia coli, high biocompatibility, and significantly improved wound healing (1.3% wound area after 2 weeks) compared to the control group (31%).
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with artificially induced wounds.
effective_dosage: Not specified (hydrogel film composition included GSE and SNP at 3%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grapefruit-derived nanovectors (GNVs) conjugated with a HER2-specific aptamer (HA1) could enhance targeted drug delivery and antitumor activity in HER2+ breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that HA1-conjugated GNVs effectively promoted internalization into HER2+ breast cancer cells and tumor spheroids in vitro, and significantly enhanced drug delivery and antitumor activity in vivo.
population_specificity: HER2-overexpressing breast cancer cells and tumor models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of green solvents (DES and aqueous glycerol) combined with HVED pre-treatment for extracting polyphenols from grapefruit peels.
results_summary: The study found that using aqueous glycerol or DES reduced the required HVED energy input for polyphenol extraction, with aqueous glycerol cutting pre-treatment energy by 6 times. The same polyphenol diffusivity was achieved with significantly lower energy in aqueous glycerol compared to water.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on grapefruit peels)
effective_dosage: Energy input varied between 7.27 and 218 kJ/kg

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop freeze-dried grapefruit-based food ingredients with high molecular weight solutes (gum arabic and bamboo fiber) to improve nutritional and antioxidant properties.
results_summary: Freeze-drying with gum arabic and bamboo fiber preserved antioxidant capacity by protecting flavonoids and vitamins, with optimal drying times varying by formulation (24, 16, and 18 hours for F1, F2, and F3, respectively). The resulting ingredients showed potential for enhancing foods with natural fibers and micronutrients.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food ingredient study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (formulations F1, F2, F3 with varying proportions of gum arabic and bamboo fiber).
study_duration: Freeze-drying times of 24, 16, and 18 hours for respective formulations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grapefruit juice could significantly inhibit methadone metabolism, leading to opioid toxicity.
results_summary: The study found that grapefruit juice inhibits CYP3A4, increasing methadone serum levels, and reported a case where this interaction caused opioid toxicity. It suggests advising patients in opioid treatment programs about this interaction.
population_specificity: A 51-year-old male in an opioid treatment program receiving 90 mg oral methadone daily.
effective_dosage: Approximately 500 mL/day of grapefruit juice for 3 consecutive days.
interactions: Grapefruit juice inhibits CYP3A4, increasing methadone serum levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cleansing effects of grapefruit seed extract (GSE) on Candida albicans biofilms on denture-base resin and its impact on the resin's mechanical and surface properties.
results_summary: The study found that 1% GSE almost completely eliminated C. albicans biofilms after 5 minutes, while 0.1% GSE and combinations with Polident® showed significant inhibitory effects. GSE solutions also demonstrated persistent biofilm inhibition without damaging the resin's surface or mechanical properties.
population_specificity: Denture-base resin discs with C. albicans biofilms (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 0.1% and 1% GSE solutions, applied for 5 minutes.
study_duration: 5 minutes for biofilm treatment; 7 days for resin immersion tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a chitosan-salicylic acid graft copolymer (CTS-g-SA) on the storability and postharvest quality of grapefruit, specifically focusing on suppressing mold and delaying fruit softening.
results_summary: The graft copolymer treatment significantly reduced green mold caused by Penicillium digitatum, maintained fruit firmness without compromising quality, and inhibited cell wall-modifying enzymes and polysaccharide solubilization linked to softening.
population_specificity: Postharvest grapefruit fruits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if nonpathogenic E. coli is a suitable surrogate for Salmonella in citrus washing and to evaluate the effectiveness of packingline processes in removing bacteria from grapefruit.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in bacterial reduction between E. coli and Salmonella in lab-scale tests, and pilot packingline processes reduced E. coli populations below detectable levels, demonstrating their effectiveness as corrective measures.
population_specificity: Grapefruit (inoculated with E. coli or Salmonella) processed on pilot packinglines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective and therapeutic anti-osteoporotic effects of grapefruit juice (GFJ) in a rat model of prednisolone-induced osteoporosis.
results_summary: GFJ treatment increased bone density, mineral content, and calcium levels, improved femur strength, and modulated biomarkers like alkaline phosphatase and insulin-like growth factor 1. It also influenced the RANKL/OPG axis, suggesting a potential mechanism for its anti-osteoporotic effects.
population_specificity: Rats with prednisolone-induced osteoporosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop non-destructive, rapid methods for determining rind biochemical properties of 'Marsh' grapefruit using Vis/NIR spectroscopy and chemometrics.
results_summary: The study successfully developed excellent models for measuring sucrose, total flavonoids, and chlorophyll b in grapefruit rind, with high accuracy (R² up to 0.99) and predictive reliability (RPD up to 12.37). The method was validated across different production regions and storage durations.
population_specificity: 'Marsh' grapefruit harvested from different production regions, analyzed before and after cold storage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether endogenous exosomes could enhance the targeted delivery efficiency of grapefruit-derived nanovectors (GNVs) to tumors, particularly in reducing liver sequestration and redirecting GNVs to the lungs and tumors.
results_summary: The study found that pre-injection of peripheral blood-derived exosomes reduced GNV deposition in the liver and redirected them to the lungs and tumors in breast and melanoma mouse models, enhancing the therapeutic efficiency of drugs (doxorubicin or paclitaxel) delivered by GNVs for lung metastases. CD36 and IGFR1 receptor-mediated pathways were critical in inhibiting GNV entry into liver macrophages.
population_specificity: Tumor-bearing mice (breast cancer and melanoma models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grapefruit-derived nanovectors (GNVs) could effectively deliver targeted drugs and siRNA to overcome multidrug resistance (MDR) in colon cancer cells.
results_summary: GNVs loaded with aptamer increased doxorubicin accumulation in MDR LoVo cells and enhanced targeted delivery to tumors. The combination of Dox, LA1 aptamer, and P-gp siRNA in GNVs more effectively inhibited proliferation, induced apoptosis, and downregulated P-gp expression compared to free Dox or GNVs with Dox alone.
population_specificity: Multidrug-resistant LoVo colon cancer cells (in vitro and in vivo models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review drug interactions caused by fruit juices other than grapefruit juice, highlighting grapefruit juice's known severe interactions due to its inhibition of cytochrome P450 3A4 and P-glycoprotein.
results_summary: The study confirmed grapefruit juice's strong potential for dangerous drug interactions, unlike other fruit juices, which showed less severe effects. Grapefruit juice's inhibition of metabolic enzymes can lead to deadly outcomes when co-ingested with certain medications.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of RCTs involving various populations)
interactions: Grapefruit juice interacts with medications by inhibiting cytochrome P450 3A4 and P-glycoprotein, leading to increased drug bioavailability and potential toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the storage stability and microbial modeling of grapefruit juice treated with UV-C light and trans-cinnamaldehyde (trans-CAH).
results_summary: Treated and some untreated grapefruit juice remained stable for up to 9 days without physicochemical or microbial changes. Higher combinations of UV-C light and trans-CAH maintained microbial load below 100 CFU/mL for up to 15 days, with trans-CAH having a greater inhibitory effect on microbial growth than UV-C alone.
population_specificity: Grapefruit juice (Rubi red grapefruit, Citrus × paradisi).
effective_dosage: UV-C light (0, 10, 20 min) and trans-CAH (0, 25, 50 μg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the strategies of Penicillium digitatum during pathogenesis on citrus, specifically assessing the effects of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) at different pH levels on cell-wall-degrading enzyme activity.
results_summary: Treatment with NaHCO3 under alkaline pH delayed polygalacturonase and pectin lyase activity but rapidly increased pectin methyl esterase activity, suggesting a pathogen strategy to lower pH for optimal enzyme action.
population_specificity: Albedo plugs (citrus fruit tissue)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of bergamottin, a compound from grapefruit juice, on the invasiveness of human glioma cells.
results_summary: Bergamottin significantly inhibited migration and invasion of glioma cells, reduced MMP-9 expression and secretion, and decreased Rac1-GTP activity, but had no effect on cell division cycle 42. Activated Rac1 restored migration and invasion in treated cells.
population_specificity: Human glioma cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of freeze-drying, gum arabic, bamboo fibre addition, and microwave pretreatment on the phenolic content, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties of grapefruit.
results_summary: Freeze-drying with gum arabic and bamboo fibre significantly increased total phenolics, antioxidant activity, and anti-inflammatory effects (via nitric oxide inhibition in macrophages). Microwave pretreatment further enhanced these benefits without cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: In vitro study using RAW 264.7 macrophages.
effective_dosage: Gum arabic (1.27 g per 100 g), bamboo fibre (0.76 g per 100 g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of microwave-assisted hot water treatment (MW-HWT) and traditional hot water treatment (HWT) on grapefruit quality and their efficacy against the Mexican fruit fly.
results_summary: MW-HWT was as effective as HWT in pest control but took less time (130 min vs. 188 min) and had a lesser impact on grapefruit quality, affecting weight, color, firmness, and other physicochemical properties. The essential oil composition, primarily d-limonene and β-myrcene, remained unaffected.
population_specificity: Grapefruits treated for pest control.
effective_dosage: Not specified (temperature and duration: 48°C for 6 min in core).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of grapefruit juice on 11β-HSD2 enzyme activity in vivo, both at rest and after intense exercise, and its potential association with blood pressure.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice significantly decreased baseline 11β-HSD2 enzyme activity and salivary cortisone levels compared to the control. Intense exercise increased salivary cortisone and cortisol but did not further alter enzyme activity. No additive effect was observed between grapefruit juice and exercise.
population_specificity: 18 subjects (specific demographics not detailed)
study_duration: Single ingestion prior to testing (acute effect)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antioxidative and functional effects of grapefruit seed extract (GSE) on the quality and storage characteristics of chicken breast.
results_summary: GSE improved water holding capacity, hardness, chewiness, and color of chicken breast, while delaying lipid peroxidation and exhibiting antimicrobial effects during cold storage. The 0.1% GSE group showed increased flavor and total acceptability scores, and higher GSE concentrations significantly reduced oxidative and microbial spoilage markers.
population_specificity: Chicken breast samples treated with GSE.
study_duration: Duration of cold storage not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to collect and present clinically relevant interactions of oral anticancer drugs with grapefruit juice based on scientific reports and product characteristics.
results_summary: The study highlights the importance of investigating interactions between grapefruit juice and oral anticancer drugs due to the growing number of cancer patients who may face such issues, but specific results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Cancer patients receiving oral anticancer therapy.
interactions: Grapefruit juice interactions with oral anticancer drugs are mentioned, but specifics are not provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-temperature conditioning on chilling injury and retention of health-promoting compounds in Rio Red grapefruits during cold storage.
results_summary: Low-temperature conditioning significantly reduced chilling injury and helped retain or increase levels of most health-promoting compounds, such as limonin, while maintaining fruit quality. No significant differences were observed in lycopene, narirutin, poncirin, furocoumarins, and radical scavenging activity across treatments.
population_specificity: Rio Red grapefruits (Citrus paradisi Macf)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (storage conditions: 11°C, 5°C, or 16°C for 7 days followed by 5°C)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antimicrobial effectiveness of grapefruit seed extract (GSE) alone and in combination with malic acid (MA) against foodborne pathogens on fresh-cut lettuce.
results_summary: The combined treatment (1% MA + 0.5% GSE) showed the greatest reduction in bacterial counts, with maximum reductions of 4.96, 4.80, and 3.95 log CFU/g for E. coli O157:H7, S. Typhimurium, and L. monocytogenes, respectively, after 14 days. The combination was more effective than either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Fresh-cut lettuce artificially inoculated with foodborne pathogens.
effective_dosage: 0.5% GSE (alone and in combination with 1% MA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial efficacy of nano-zinc oxide formulations (Zinkicide SG4 and SG6) against citrus canker and other diseases in grapefruit and sweet orange.
results_summary: Zinkicide formulations demonstrated superior antimicrobial activity compared to commercial copper and zinc oxide treatments, effectively reducing citrus canker incidence and controlling fungal diseases like citrus scab and melanose without causing phytotoxicity.
population_specificity: Sweet orange (Citrus sinensis) leaves and 'Ruby Red' grapefruit (C. paradisi) fruit.
effective_dosage: Not specified (in vitro MIC ranged from 31 to 500 µg/ml).
study_duration: Field trials conducted in 2014 and 2015 (duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-Eimeria efficacy and oxidative stress-reducing effects of grapefruit peel extract (GF) and commercial naringenin (NAR) in naturally infected lambs, comparing them to the standard drug toltrazuril (TTZ).
results_summary: GF and NAR showed high anticoccidial efficacy (89.65% and 91.76%, respectively), reduced oxidative stress, and improved mean daily weight gains in infected lambs, though TTZ was slightly more effective (99.63%). Pharmacokinetic profiles indicated rapid absorption of GF and NAR.
population_specificity: Naturally Eimeria-infected growing lambs.
effective_dosage: 5mg/kg body weight daily for GF and NAR; 20mg/kg body weight for TTZ (administered on days 0 and 15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether grapefruit juice (GFJ) could safely and effectively increase tacrolimus (TAC) blood concentration in patients with connective tissue diseases who had insufficient TAC levels despite high doses.
results_summary: GFJ increased TAC levels approximately threefold (from 4.3±2.4 ng/mL to 13.8±6.9 ng/mL) and improved clinical outcomes in most cases without severe adverse events, while also reducing glucocorticoid and TAC dosages. However, TAC concentration fluctuations were observed in some cases.
population_specificity: Patients with connective tissue diseases and insufficient TAC blood concentration despite receiving ≥3 mg/day of TAC.
interactions: GFJ increased tacrolimus (TAC) concentration; monitoring is advised due to potential influence on concomitantly used drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of naringin, a main flavonoid in grapefruit, on glucose intolerance, oxidative stress, and ketonemia in type 1 diabetic rats.
results_summary: Naringin improved fasting plasma insulin, hepatic glycogen content, and markers of oxidative stress and ketoacidosis but did not affect fasting blood glucose levels. It ameliorated complications of diabetic ketoacidosis without exhibiting hypoglycemic effects.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats with streptozotocin-induced type 1 diabetes.
study_duration: Daily treatment duration not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of grapefruit juice on the pharmacokinetics of dapoxetine, specifically its absorption and clearance, using midazolam as a probe for CYP3A4 activity.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice significantly increased the absorption and reduced the clearance of dapoxetine, likely due to CYP3A4 inhibition, while pomegranate juice had minimal effects. The changes in pharmacokinetics were mild but warrant caution in coadministration.
population_specificity: 12 healthy subjects
effective_dosage: 250 ml of undiluted grapefruit juice daily for three consecutive days
interactions: Grapefruit juice inhibits CYP3A4, affecting dapoxetine pharmacokinetics; pomegranate juice showed little interaction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether miR-18a encapsulated in grapefruit-derived nanovectors (GNV) could inhibit liver metastasis by inducing M1 macrophages and activating immune cells.
results_summary: The study found that miR-18a delivered via GNV effectively inhibited liver metastasis by inducing M1 macrophages, which activated NK and NKT cells through IL-12. Depletion of macrophages or knockout of IFNγ eliminated the anti-metastatic effect.
population_specificity: The study focused on mice models of liver metastasis, specifically colon cancer metastasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight clinically relevant drug-food interactions, including those involving grapefruit, and their potential impact on drug efficacy and toxicity.
results_summary: The study emphasizes that grapefruit juice can significantly alter drug plasma concentrations, leading to decreased efficacy or life-threatening toxicity, particularly with medications like cardiovascular drugs, warfarin, and immunosuppressants. It underscores the need for thorough dietary recall and health history to mitigate risks.
population_specificity: General clinical populations, including aging individuals, transplant recipients, cancer patients, and those with malnutrition or HIV infection.
interactions: Grapefruit juice interacts with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, opioid analgesics, cardiovascular medications, warfarin, anticancer drugs, and immunosuppressants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of grapefruit-derived nanovectors (GNVs) for targeted delivery of miR17 to treat brain tumors in mice via intranasal administration.
results_summary: FA-pGNVs effectively delivered miR17 to brain tumors, selectively targeting folate receptor-positive GL-26 cells, delaying tumor growth without polyethylenimine toxicity. The study suggests a noninvasive therapeutic approach for brain-related diseases.
population_specificity: Mice with GL-26 brain tumors (folate receptor-positive).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how grapefruit juice affects the pharmacokinetics of pirfenidone compared to fasting and fed conditions.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice modestly reduced overall oral absorption and significantly reduced peak concentrations of pirfenidone, similar to the effects of food ingestion. No adverse events were observed, but the reduction in peak concentrations raises concerns for clinical efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: 12 healthy Chinese male volunteers
study_duration: Three-period crossover study with a 7-day washout period
interactions: Grapefruit juice significantly reduced peak concentrations of pirfenidone compared to fasting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of concurrent ingestion of grapefruit juice and carbamazepine overdose in a patient with epilepsy.
results_summary: The study found that grapefruit juice ingestion alongside carbamazepine overdose led to severe toxicity, requiring medical intervention. The patient recovered after treatment with gastric lavage, activated charcoal, and hemoperfusion.
population_specificity: A 23-year-old man with a history of epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the nutritional and functional value of grapefruit jams produced using conventional heating, osmotic dehydration, and microwave techniques, focusing on vitamin, organic acid, and phytochemical content and stability during storage.
results_summary: Osmotic dehydration led to greater losses of organic acids and vitamin C compared to heating, while microwave treatments produced jams with similar nutritional value to conventional methods but in less time. The study highlighted the impact of processing techniques on bioactive compound retention.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on grapefruit jam processing methods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of postharvest degreening and storage on phytochemical content in Rio Red grapefruit.
results_summary: Degreening improved peel color without affecting juice quality, increased ascorbic acid after 35 days, and temporarily altered limonin, flavonoids, and furocoumarin levels after 7 days. Ethylene treatment significantly influenced phytochemical content, particularly in the short term.
population_specificity: Rio Red grapefruit (postharvest study, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of grapefruit juice consumption, specifically its flavanones, on vascular function in healthy postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice consumption significantly reduced arterial stiffness (carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity) but did not affect endothelial function, blood pressure, glucose metabolism, or biomarkers of inflammation and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women aged 50-65, within 3-10 years since menopause, BMI 19-30, and waist size >88 cm.
effective_dosage: 340 mL grapefruit juice daily, providing 210 mg naringenin glycosides.
study_duration: 6 months per intervention, with a 2-month washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of grapefruit juice (GFJ) on the systemic exposure and bioavailability of ibrutinib, a drug used for treating certain cancers.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice increased the absolute bioavailability of ibrutinib from 8.4% (fed state without GFJ) to 15.9% (fed state with GFJ), indicating enhanced absorption. Adverse events were mild to moderate and resolved without lasting effects.
population_specificity: Participants receiving ibrutinib treatment (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: 140 mg oral ibrutinib with GFJ intake before dosing.
study_duration: Single-dose intervention (duration not specified beyond dosing).
interactions: Grapefruit juice increased systemic exposure of ibrutinib.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grapefruit-derived nanovectors (GNV) coated with inflammatory-related receptor membranes (IGNVs) could enhance homing to inflammatory tumor tissues and improve therapeutic outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that IGNVs effectively homed to inflammatory tumor tissues, significantly inhibited tumor growth in two models, and reduced inflammation in colitis. Blocking specific receptors on IGNVs inhibited their homing ability, supporting their targeted therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Mouse models of inflammatory-driven diseases, including tumor models and dextran sulfate sodium-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects of grapefruit extract in overweight insulin-resistant rats.
results_summary: Grapefruit extract reduced weight gain, lowered serum insulin and liver TBARS levels, improved leptin/adiponectin ratio, and reduced TNFα and TLR2 expression, indicating benefits for inflammation and oxidative stress in insulin-resistant rats.
population_specificity: Overweight insulin-resistant male Wistar rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which grapefruit juice (GFJ) lowers blood glucose levels in diabetic rats.
results_summary: GFJ improved glucose intolerance in diabetic rats by suppressing hepatic gluconeogenesis, as evidenced by elevated glucokinase activity and hepatic glycogen concentrations, along with suppressed G6Pase and PEPCK activities. However, GFJ did not improve fasting plasma insulin levels.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (250-300 g body weight) with induced diabetes.
effective_dosage: 3.0 ml/kg body weight of GFJ administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a grapefruit-based model to simulate diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) for training podiatry trainees.
results_summary: The grapefruit model successfully simulated a DFU, with podiatrists rating its utility as a training tool at 61.9%. The model's fidelity could be improved with more accurate measurement techniques.
population_specificity: Podiatrists from the North West of England (50 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of olfactory stimulation with grapefruit oil on autonomic nerve activity and physiological functions such as lipolysis, thermogenesis, and food intake.
results_summary: Olfactory stimulation with grapefruit oil increased sympathetic nerve activity, leading to enhanced lipolysis, thermogenesis, and blood pressure, while decreasing food intake. These effects were mediated by limonene and involved the suprachiasmatic nucleus and histamine pathways.
population_specificity: Rats and mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether bergamottin (BGM) from grapefruit juice could inhibit STAT3 activation in multiple myeloma (MM) cells and assess its potential as a therapeutic agent.
results_summary: BGM suppressed STAT3 activation in MM cells by inhibiting JAK1/2 and c-Src phosphorylation, upregulated SHP-1 phosphatase, and induced apoptosis. It also enhanced the effects of bortezomib and thalidomide.
population_specificity: Multiple myeloma (MM) cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of storage temperature and low-temperature conditioning on bioactive compounds and chilling injury (CI) in 'Star Ruby' grapefruit.
results_summary: Fruits stored at 11°C showed no chilling injury (CI), while those at 2°C had the highest CI. Conditioning treatment reduced CI and helped retain ascorbic acid longer, while 11°C storage was more effective for short-term preservation of carotenoids and flavonoids.
population_specificity: 'Star Ruby' grapefruit (Citrus paradisi Macf.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of grapefruit juice on the antiplatelet activity of clopidogrel, both after a loading dose and during maintenance therapy.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice significantly increased mean platelet reactivity (PRU) after a clopidogrel loading dose, but the effect was not statistically significant during maintenance therapy. The proportion of subjects with high platelet reactivity was higher with grapefruit juice, though not statistically significant in either protocol.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 300 mg loading dose of clopidogrel; 75 mg/day maintenance dose for 7 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grapefruit juice affects the metabolism and efficacy of clopidogrel by inhibiting CYP3A4 and CYP2C19 enzymes.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice significantly reduced the peak plasma concentration and bioavailability of clopidogrel's active metabolite, impairing its platelet-inhibitory effect. The study concluded that grapefruit juice may reduce clopidogrel's efficacy and should be avoided during therapy.
population_specificity: 14 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 200 ml of grapefruit juice three times daily
interactions: Marked interaction with clopidogrel, reducing its efficacy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects of habitual grapefruit consumption in overweight/obese adults, particularly those with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: Grapefruit consumption did not significantly reduce inflammation or oxidative stress overall, but showed a tendency to lower oxidative stress in adults with MetS or high baseline F2-isoprostane concentrations. No significant differences were observed in plasma hsCRP or sVCAM-1 concentrations between groups.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese men and women, including a subsample with metabolic syndrome (MetS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether grapefruit juice could mitigate cytogenetic and testicular damage caused by the antiarrhythmic drug amiodarone in albino rats.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice reduced chromosomal aberrations, DNA damage, and testicular alterations induced by amiodarone, suggesting protective antioxidant effects.
population_specificity: Albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of grapefruit intake on endogenous estrogen levels in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Whole grapefruit intake significantly increased endogenous estrone-3-sulfate (E1S) levels by 26% at peak effect (8 hours), while fresh juice, bottled juice, and soda intake lowered estradiol (E2) levels. No changes in mean estrone (E1) or estradiol (E2) were observed with whole fruit intake.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women recruited through the Love/Avon Army of Women.
effective_dosage: Not specified (whole grapefruit, 2 juices, and 1 grapefruit soda were tested).
study_duration: 2 weeks of grapefruit intake (plus a 3-week run-in and 1-week wash-out).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of grapefruit-derived nanovectors for targeted drug delivery, assessing their safety, targeting efficiency, and therapeutic effects in tumor models.
results_summary: Grapefruit-derived nanovectors effectively delivered various therapeutic agents to specific cells, enhanced tumor growth inhibition in animal models, and demonstrated lower toxicity compared to synthetic nanoparticles without crossing the placental barrier.
population_specificity: Animal models (mice, including pregnant mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal conditions for ultrasound-assisted extraction (UAE) of all-trans-lycopene from red grapefruit and compare its efficiency to conventional solvent extraction (CSE).
results_summary: UAE significantly improved extraction yield and reduced extraction time compared to CSE, with peak efficiency at 30 minutes and 30°C. The study also noted degradation of all-trans-lycopene into cis-isomers under ultrasonic treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on grapefruit extraction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interactions between grapefruit juice and various drugs, focusing on its inhibition of CYP3A4 and other cytochrome P450 isoenzymes, and the resulting clinical consequences.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice inhibits CYP3A4 and other cytochrome P450 isoenzymes, increasing plasma concentrations of certain drugs and raising the risk of overdose and adverse effects. The variability in grapefruit juice composition and individual enzyme efficiency makes predicting the magnitude of interactions difficult.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers (typically around 10 per pharmacokinetic study) and patients taking medications with known grapefruit interactions.
interactions: Immunosuppressants, some statins, benzodiazepines, most calcium channel blockers, indinavir, and carbamazepine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of ethylene-induced degreening and storage on bioactive compounds in Star Ruby grapefruit.
results_summary: Degreening increased nomilin levels but decreased flavonoids like narirutin, naringin, and poncirin after 35 days of storage. It had no significant effect on most other bioactive compounds, taste, odor, or decay.
population_specificity: Star Ruby grapefruits (Citrus paradisi Macf.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of grapefruit juice on the pharmacokinetics of colchicine in healthy volunteers, contrary to existing label warnings.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice did not significantly affect colchicine pharmacokinetics, and no significant adverse events were reported. Seville orange juice reduced colchicine absorption and delayed peak concentration, but clinical significance remains unclear.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers (72.7% male, 90.9% white for grapefruit juice group).
effective_dosage: 240 mL of undiluted grapefruit juice twice daily.
interactions: None mentioned for grapefruit juice; Seville orange juice reduced colchicine absorption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential role of grapefruit juice in enhancing naratriptan toxicity, leading to mesenteric ischemia.
results_summary: The study reported a case where grapefruit juice, a known P450 inhibitor, may have exacerbated naratriptan toxicity, resulting in severe mesenteric ischemia, organ failure, and extensive bowel resection. The findings suggest grapefruit juice can interact adversely with certain medications.
population_specificity: A 61-year-old woman hospitalized in ICU.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of grapefruit juice and its components (naringin and naringenin) on the survival and adherence of Salmonella Typhimurium to intestinal epithelial cells.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice significantly reduced Salmonella survival compared to controls, with naringenin (NGE) at 100-200 μg/mL reducing bacterial adherence by 57-73%. Low pH enhanced NGE's inhibitory effects on Salmonella growth and adherence.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Salmonella Typhimurium and intestinal epithelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether daily grapefruit consumption reduces body weight, blood pressure, and improves lipid profiles in overweight adults.
results_summary: Grapefruit consumption did not significantly reduce body weight compared to the control group but showed modest weight loss, significant reductions in waist circumference and systolic blood pressure, and improvements in total cholesterol and LDL levels compared to baseline values.
population_specificity: Overweight adults (N = 74)
effective_dosage: Half a fresh Rio-Red grapefruit with each meal (3 times daily)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of grapefruit juice (GFJ) and ritonavir (RTV) on the pharmacokinetics of lopinavir (LPV) in rats, focusing on bioavailability enhancement.
results_summary: GFJ significantly increased LPV plasma levels, with effects similar to RTV, and enhanced LPV's apparent permeability in the ileum. Both GFJ and RTV showed comparable inhibition of LPV metabolism in rat intestinal microsomes.
population_specificity: Rats
study_duration: Single dose and multidose pretreatment (duration not specified)
interactions: GFJ interacts with LPV by inhibiting CYP3A and P-gp, similar to RTV.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the prevalence of grapefruit consumption in emergency department patients and assess its potential risk for fruit-drug interactions.
results_summary: Among 162 patients, 36% reported grapefruit consumption, and 7% were prescribed medications with a risk of interaction. No adverse drug events were linked to grapefruit interactions, though calcium channel blockers and statins were identified as high-risk medications.
population_specificity: Patients admitted to a tertiary care emergency department.
effective_dosage: Not specified (regardless of form or frequency).
study_duration: Observational period from July to December 2009.
interactions: Calcium channel blockers and HMG-CoA-reductase inhibitors (statins).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grapefruit juice affects the bioavailability and elimination of tolvaptan, a CYP3A4 substrate.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice increased the bioavailability of tolvaptan (1.86-fold higher C(max) and 1.56-fold higher AUC(∞)) but did not alter its elimination half-life. Adverse events were consistent with tolvaptan's aquaretic effects, including urinary frequency, thirst, and dry mouth.
population_specificity: 20 healthy subjects
effective_dosage: 60 mg tolvaptan with 240 mL water or grapefruit juice
study_duration: 48-hour postdose monitoring (washout period of 72 h between doses)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether regular consumption of grapefruit juice affects serum atorvastatin levels, effectiveness, and safety in patients on stable atorvastatin therapy.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice slightly increased serum atorvastatin levels without meaningful effects on lipid profiles or adverse liver/muscle effects. Reducing atorvastatin dosage with grapefruit juice co-ingestion led to lower serum levels and slightly unfavorable lipid changes.
population_specificity: Patients on extended stable atorvastatin treatment (10, 20, or 40 mg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether grapefruit juice could induce a viable but nonculturable (VBNC) state in foodborne pathogens and assess their potential to resuscitate.
results_summary: The study found that grapefruit juice's harsh environment (low pH, antimicrobial compounds) caused varying VBNC states in pathogens, with some (E. coli O157:H7, S. Typhimurium, S. flexneri) able to resuscitate under certain conditions, while L. monocytogenes lost viability entirely.
population_specificity: In vitro bacterial pathogens (E. coli O157:H7, S. Typhimurium, L. monocytogenes, S. flexneri).
effective_dosage: Not specified (inoculum sizes varied but exact amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of grapefruit juice (GFJ) on glucose tolerance and metformin-induced lactic acidosis in non-diabetic rats.
results_summary: GFJ significantly lowered fasting blood glucose levels but did not affect plasma insulin levels. GFJ combined with metformin increased lactic acid levels, suggesting a potential risk of exacerbating lactic acidosis in diabetic patients taking metformin.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (non-diabetic).
effective_dosage: 1.0, 2.0, 3.0 ml/kg body weight (group A); 3.0 ml/kg body weight (groups B and C).
interactions: GFJ may exacerbate lactic acidosis when taken with metformin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nootkatone, a constituent of grapefruit, activates AMPK and improves metabolic outcomes, including obesity prevention and physical performance enhancement.
results_summary: Nootkatone activated AMPK in cells and mice, increased energy expenditure, reduced weight gain and fat accumulation, and improved endurance capacity. It also mitigated hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, and hyperleptinemia in mice fed high-fat and high-sucrose diets.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice and BALB/c mice (for endurance testing).
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg body weight (acute administration); 0.1% to 0.3% (wt/wt) in diet (long-term intake).
study_duration: Long-term intake duration not specified in abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate quercetin, a bioflavonoid found in grapefruit, as a potential therapeutic agent for managing Type 2 diabetes and its complications.
results_summary: Quercetin demonstrated effects similar to metformin in cell line models and showed promise in vivo for managing Type 2 diabetes and its oxidative stress-related complications, though further studies are needed to improve bioavailability and establish dosing.
population_specificity: Not specified (cell line models and in vivo studies mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Sinetrol-XPur (a polyphenolic citrus dry extract) in weight management, metabolic parameters, and inflammatory, glycemic, and oxidative status in overweight individuals.
results_summary: Sinetrol-XPur significantly reduced waist and hip circumference, abdominal fat, inflammatory markers, and oxidative stress compared to placebo, with no adverse effects observed.
population_specificity: Overweight subjects (N=47 in the tested group, N=48 in the placebo group).
effective_dosage: Twice daily with meals (specific amount not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of grapefruit juice on the absorption and metabolism of cortisone acetate in patients with Addison's disease.
results_summary: Grapefruit juice significantly increased the area under the curve for serum cortisol and elevated cortisol levels 2.6 hours after cortisone acetate administration, indicating enhanced cortisol availability to tissues. It also altered the urinary cortisol metabolite ratios.
population_specificity: 17 patients with Addison's disease on stable cortisone acetate replacement therapy.
interactions: Increased cortisol availability when co-administered with cortisone acetate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the effect of green coffee extract on waist circumference, body mass index, and body weight through an umbrella review of interventional meta-analyses.
results_summary: The study found that green coffee extract significantly reduced body weight, BMI, and waist circumference, with optimal effects observed at dosages ≤600 mg/day and interventions lasting >7 weeks.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a plant-based supplement containing green coffee extract could reduce postprandial glycemia and glycemic index in carbohydrate meals.
results_summary: The supplement significantly reduced glycemic response for instant noodle soup and white rice but not for strawberry sorbet, suggesting it may lower postprandial glycemia and GI for certain carbohydrate foods.
population_specificity: Twenty-three women with abdominal obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro immunomodulatory effects of green coffee extract (GCE) and assess its impact on immune markers in healthy individuals through a clinical trial.
results_summary: GCE significantly inhibited LPS-induced NF-κB phosphorylation and MCP-1-induced chemotaxis while enhancing phagocytosis, IgG production, and NK cell activity. It also modulated TH1/TH2 cytokine production and reduced pro-inflammatory markers like IL-6, TNF-α, and CRP.
population_specificity: Apparently healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of decaffeinated green coffee extract (DGCE) on anthropometric indices, blood glucose, leptin, adiponectin, and neuropeptide Y (NPY) in obese breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in anthropometric indices, blood glucose, leptin, adiponectin, or NPY levels between the DGCE and placebo groups after 12 weeks of supplementation. DGCE did not demonstrate measurable benefits for the studied outcomes in this population.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors with obesity (BMI 31.62 ± 4.97 kg/m²), aged 18-70 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of green coffee extract on dopaminergic transmission and its potential neuroprotective role in Parkinson's disease models.
results_summary: Green coffee extract showed mild antioxidant activity, reduced catalepsy in mice, and modulated dopaminergic transmission in rats with striatal lesions, but did not prevent monoamine depletion.
population_specificity: Mice and rats (animal models of Parkinson's disease).
effective_dosage: 100 or 400 mg/kg for green coffee extract; 31.2 mg/kg for caffeine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of soil-applied systemic acquired resistance (SAR) inducers compared to foliar sprays in controlling citrus canker caused by *Xanthomonas citri* subsp. *citri* in young 'Ray Ruby' grapefruit trees.
results_summary: Soil-applied SAR inducers reduced citrus canker incidence depending on rate, frequency, and timing, though efficacy varied during extreme weather events. Foliar copper hydroxide and streptomycin sprays consistently reduced disease incidence across seasons.
population_specificity: 3- and 4-year-old 'Ray Ruby' grapefruit trees in southeastern Florida.
effective_dosage: Acibenzolar-S-methyl (0.2 g a.i. per tree), imidacloprid, and thiamethoxam at various rates and frequencies (1, 2, or 4 applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential weight-reducing effects of grapefruit, as a polyphenol-rich food, by examining its impact on gut microbiota composition in obese individuals.
results_summary: The study suggests that grapefruit, along with other polyphenol-rich foods, may reduce body weight in obese individuals by favoring the growth of Bacteroidetes over Firmicutes in the gut microbiota, due to their differential sensitivity to phenolic compounds and glycan metabolism.
population_specificity: Obese individuals
effective_dosage: Not specified (mentioned "daily intake" but no exact dosage)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether caffeine (CAF) and green coffee extract (GCE) could reduce hepatic steatosis in lean female rats with diet-induced liver fat accumulation.
results_summary: GCE, but not CAF alone, led to lower hepatic triglyceride levels, potentially through mechanisms involving reduced mTOR phosphorylation, diacylglycerol levels, hexosylceramide/ceramide ratios, and VLDL receptor expression. However, neither treatment alleviated hepatic steatosis overall.
population_specificity: Lean female Sprague-Dawley rats with diet-induced hepatic steatosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on the effects of green coffee extract (GCE) supplementation on glycemic indices and lipid profile.
results_summary: GCE supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, serum insulin, and total cholesterol, with improvements in other lipid markers in specific subgroups. The effects of chlorogenic acid dosage on some outcomes were non-linear.
population_specificity: 766 participants across 14 clinical trials (both genders included, with some subgroup analyses focusing on females or studies lasting ≥8 weeks).
study_duration: Varied, with some analyses confined to studies ≥8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to conduct a comprehensive systematic review and dose-response meta-analysis to evaluate the effects of Green Coffee Extract (GCE) supplementation on anthropometric measures, addressing limitations of previous meta-analyses.
results_summary: The study found that GCE supplementation significantly reduced body weight, BMI, and waist circumference but had no significant effect on body fat percentage or waist-to-hip ratio. No significant dose-response relationship was observed for chlorogenic acid (CGA) dosage.
population_specificity: 897 participants across 15 randomized clinical trials (RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of green coffee extract (GCE) on serum lipid profile, adiponectin levels, and hepatic steatosis in patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: GCE supplementation significantly reduced BMI and improved serum lipid profile (increased HDL cholesterol, decreased total cholesterol and triglycerides), but did not significantly affect hepatic steatosis grade, liver enzymes, or adiponectin levels.
population_specificity: Patients with NAFLD aged 20-60 years and BMI of 25-35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of low-dose green coffee extract on body weight, serum lipids, and TNF-α levels in high-fat diet-induced obese rats.
results_summary: Green coffee extract reduced body weight, total cholesterol, and triglycerides at doses of 10, 20, and 40 mg/kg BW/day, lowered LDL-cholesterol at 20 mg/kg BW/day, and decreased TNF-α levels at 40 mg/kg BW/day. The study supports its potential as a functional nutrient for obesity management.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese male Wistar rats (Rattus norvegicus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of green coffee bean extract (GCBE) supplementation on blood pressure indices, specifically systolic and diastolic blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in both systolic (-3.093 mmHg) and diastolic (-2.170 mmHg) blood pressure after GCBE supplementation, with low heterogeneity among studies. Subgroup analysis showed greater improvements in hypertensive patients, doses <400 mg, and interventions lasting 4 weeks.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients and general populations from clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Green Coffee Extract (GCE) and Chlorogenic acids (CGA) on body weight, BMI, and waist circumference in adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in BMI but no significant changes in body weight or waist circumference. Subgroup analysis showed greater improvements in individuals with a baseline BMI ≥25 kg/m² and no effect for supplementation periods shorter than 4 weeks.
population_specificity: Adults, with subgroup analysis focusing on those with baseline BMI ≥25 kg/m².
study_duration: Varied, with short-term (<4 weeks) showing no effect.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of decaffeinated green coffee bean extract (GCE) on metabolic syndrome components, including anthropometric indices, glycaemic control, blood pressure, lipid profile, insulin resistance, and appetite.
results_summary: GCE supplementation significantly reduced systolic blood pressure, fasting blood glucose, insulin resistance, waist circumference, and appetite compared to placebo. Weight and BMI reductions were also observed but were marginally significant, while no effects were seen on HbA1c or lipid profile.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome (Mets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacokinetic profile and apparent bioavailability of chlorogenic acids (CGA) from green coffee extract in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that over 30% of ingested cinnamic acid moieties were recovered in plasma, including metabolites, with peak levels occurring between 0.5 to 8 hours post-consumption. Urinary recovery of CGA and metabolites was 5.5%, indicating significant absorption and metabolism of green coffee CGA in humans.
population_specificity: 10 healthy adults
effective_dosage: 170 mg of CGA in a single dose of decaffeinated green coffee extract

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the chemoprotective properties, antioxidative activities, and safety of green coffee extract (GC) in supplemented bread using human cell cultures.
results_summary: GC and supplemented bread showed significantly higher antioxidative capacity and chlorogenic acid content compared to normal bread. Treatment with GC and supplemented bread reduced H2O2-induced DNA damage and inhibited cell survival in a dose-dependent manner without genotoxicity or cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: Human colon (HT29) and liver (HepG2) cells in culture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a diet enriched with green leafy vegetables and moderate carbohydrate restriction on liver and metabolic markers in patients with NAFLD over three months.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in fatty liver index (FLI), FAST score, BMI, waist circumference, fat mass, and metabolic parameters like HbA1c, triglycerides, AST, and γGT after replacing one portion of carbohydrate-rich food with green leafy vegetables for three months.
population_specificity: 24 patients with NAFLD (median age 47.5 years, 70.8% women).
effective_dosage: One portion of green leafy vegetables daily, replacing one portion of carbohydrate-rich food.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the occurrence of Giardia duodenalis and Cryptosporidium spp. (oo)cysts in green leafy vegetables from conventional and organic farms in Valencia, Spain.
results_summary: Giardia duodenalis was detected in 23.0% of samples and Cryptosporidium spp. in 7.8%, with higher contamination rates in organic crops (41.5% and 20.0%, respectively). The study suggests that organic vegetables may pose a higher risk due to fertilizer and irrigation water quality.
population_specificity: Green leafy vegetable samples from conventional (64) and organic (65) farms in Valencia, Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine optimal conditions for extracting antidiabetic compounds from green leafy vegetables and incorporating them into crackers to develop a functional antidiabetic snack.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound-assisted extraction with 44.08% ethanol, 80% amplitude, and 30 min sonication yielded the highest α-glucosidase inhibitory activity and extraction yield. Crackers with 2.5% vegetable extract baked at 140°C showed the highest phenolic content, antioxidant performance, and antidiabetic/antiobesity effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food product testing implied).
effective_dosage: 0.625%, 1.25%, or 2.5% w/w vegetable extract in crackers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increased intake of Green Leafy Vegetables (GLV) could reduce biomarkers of colonic DNA damage and inflammation in adults with high red meat consumption and low GLV intake.
results_summary: The study found that GLV intake significantly increased plasma Vitamin K1 and decreased circulating and fecal 8OHdG (a DNA damage marker) and TNFα (an inflammatory marker), but did not significantly alter fecal microbiota diversity or major taxa abundance.
population_specificity: Adults with habitual high red meat intake, low GLV intake, and BMI > 30 kg/m².
study_duration: 4 weeks (intervention period within a 12-week crossover trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether dried green leafy vegetables could improve anaemia and vitamin-A status in Ghanaian school children during the dry season.
results_summary: The study found that consuming green leafy vegetable powder significantly increased mean haemoglobin and retinol concentrations, reducing anaemia prevalence and improving vitamin-A status compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Ghanaian school children aged 4-9 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether daily consumption of a snack containing green leafy vegetables (GLVs) could improve erythrocyte long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acid (LCPUFA) status in non-pregnant Indian women.
results_summary: The treatment group showed a significant increase in erythrocyte DHA levels and total n-3 fatty acids, while the control group experienced a decline. No adverse effects on oxidative stress markers were observed.
population_specificity: Non-pregnant women aged 14-35 years from Mumbai slums.
effective_dosage: One treatment snack containing a mean of 54.1 mg alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), consumed daily.

study_goal: To examine the effects of consuming two to three extra servings of green leafy vegetables daily on bone metabolism, specifically focusing on vitamin K1's role in osteocalcin metabolism.
results_summary: Increased intake of vitamin K1-rich green leafy vegetables significantly reduced serum total osteocalcin (tOC) and undercarboxylated osteocalcin (ucOC) levels, suggesting enhanced incorporation of osteocalcin into bone matrix, while carboxylated osteocalcin (cOC) remained unchanged. No significant changes were observed with low vitamin K1 intake or the control diet.
population_specificity: Thirty middle-aged healthy individuals (mean age 61.8 ± 9.9 years, 67% male).
effective_dosage: ~200 g/day of green leafy vegetables (providing 164.3 [99.5-384.7] μg/day of vitamin K1).
study_duration: Three experimental phases, each lasting four weeks, with four-week washout periods between phases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the separation and identification of phenolic compounds in Green Leafy Vegetables (GLVs) using LC-MS and highlight their potential health benefits.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that GLVs are rich in phenolic compounds with antioxidant properties, which may improve human health and immune function. Advances in analytical techniques like LC-MS enhance the extraction and quantification of these compounds.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health focus).

study_goal: To investigate the antibacterial activity and phytochemical composition of five green leafy vegetables against five bacterial strains.
results_summary: Methanol extracts of all tested green leafy vegetables showed antibacterial activity (6-15 mm inhibition zones) against the bacterial strains. The vegetables contained proteins, carbohydrates, alkaloids, steroids, saponins, flavonoids, and tannins, suggesting moderate antibacterial activity and pharmacological potential.
population_specificity: Bacterial strains (specific strains not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term increased dietary nitrate intake from green leafy vegetables could lower blood pressure and reduce arterial stiffness in individuals with high-normal blood pressure.
results_summary: The high-nitrate diet significantly increased salivary and plasma nitrate and nitrite levels but did not reduce blood pressure or arterial stiffness compared to the low-nitrate diet. The study concluded that increasing dietary nitrate intake may not be an effective short-term strategy for lowering blood pressure in this population.
population_specificity: 38 men and women aged 30-70 years with systolic blood pressure between 120-139 mm Hg.
effective_dosage: Increased nitrate intake by at least 300 mg/day from green leafy vegetables.
study_duration: 7 days per diet intervention (high-nitrate and low-nitrate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the ability of tropical green leafy vegetables to prevent garlic-induced hepatotoxicity in rats.
results_summary: The study found that T. occidentalis and C. acontifolus significantly reduced garlic-induced liver damage (as indicated by decreased SGOT and SGPT levels) and improved serum protein and albumin levels, while other tested vegetables showed inconsistent effects.
population_specificity: Wistar strain albino rats
effective_dosage: 40% green leafy vegetable supplement alongside 4% garlic in diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutritional value and thermal treatment severity of multi-ingredient dishes containing green leafy vegetables.
results_summary: The dishes had high beta-carotene and retinol activity equivalent (RAE) due to the high proportion of leafy vegetables, but fiber content was low unless leaf stems were included. Adding meat did not significantly increase micronutrient content, and thermal treatment severity correlated with 13-cis-beta-carotene in three dishes.
population_specificity: Urban district population consuming multi-ingredient dishes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether tropical green leafy vegetables could prevent garlic-induced hemolytic anemia in rats.
results_summary: The study found that garlic (4%) induced hemolytic anemia in rats, but supplementation with certain green leafy vegetables (40%) significantly improved hematological parameters, suggesting a protective effect.
population_specificity: Wister strain albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a reliable method for determining nitrate and nitrite levels in leafy vegetables and to analyze these levels in 10 types of leafy vegetables native to the Aegean region of Turkey.
results_summary: The study developed a fast, accurate method for nitrate and nitrite determination, finding nitrate levels ranging from 354.8 mg/kg (iceberg lettuce) to 4653 mg/kg (wild radish), with nitrite levels below 26.33 mg/kg. The method showed high recovery rates (92.9–102.8%) and low variability (3.16% intraday precision).
population_specificity: Leafy vegetables native to the Aegean region of Turkey (wild radish, chicory, fennel, blessed thistle, blue mallow, chard, and others).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the bioefficacy of provitamin A carotenoids in tropical leafy vegetables indigenous to Africa using Mongolian gerbils as a model.
results_summary: The study found that small quantities of the tested leafy vegetables maintained vitamin A status in gerbils through efficient bioconversion of beta-carotene to retinol, with conversion factors ranging between 1.9 and 2.3 µg beta-carotene equivalents to 1 µg retinol. Liver vitamin A levels in the vegetable groups were significantly higher than in the negative control group.
population_specificity: Vitamin A-depleted Mongolian gerbils
effective_dosage: 35 nmol vitamin A (theoretical concentrations based on 100% bioefficacy) in the form of vegetables or retinyl acetate, administered daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of health education on mothers' feeding of green leafy vegetables (GLV) to their children at home.
results_summary: Health education significantly increased the percentage of mothers who fed GLV to their children (57% and 64% in intervention groups vs. 26% in the comparison group). Maternal literacy and family income did not diminish this effect.
population_specificity: 160 children aged 6 to 35 months and their mothers in two intervention groups and one comparison group.
effective_dosage: Single meal of cooked GLV (for one intervention group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of dietary nitrate from green leafy vegetables in enhancing nitric oxide bioavailability and its potential benefits for cardiovascular health and exercise performance.
results_summary: The study found that dietary nitrate supplementation, primarily from green leafy vegetables, enhances nitric oxide bioavailability, improves cardiovascular health markers (e.g., blood pressure, vascular function), and may boost exercise performance by increasing skeletal muscle nitrate stores.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients and older humans (specific populations mentioned); broader implications for general health and exercise performance.
effective_dosage: Not specified for green leafy vegetables; beetroot juice and sodium nitrite dosages referenced but not detailed.
study_duration: Not specified for green leafy vegetables; referenced studies varied in duration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of dietary nitrate from green leafy vegetables on mitochondrial function, focusing on its potential therapeutic role in type 2 diabetes (T2D) and related metabolic disorders.
results_summary: The study found that dietary nitrate from green leafy vegetables can serve as an alternative precursor for nitric oxide (NO), improving mitochondrial function, glucose homeostasis, and reducing oxidative stress, with protective effects observed in models of obesity, metabolic syndrome, and T2D.
population_specificity: Models of obesity, metabolic syndrome, and type 2 diabetes (experimental studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dietary nitrate from green leafy vegetables in blood pressure control and assess whether nitrate should be considered a beneficial nutrient rather than a contaminant.
results_summary: The study found that dietary nitrate from green leafy vegetables can reduce systolic blood pressure via the nitrate-nitrite-NO pathway, potentially lowering hypertension and CVD risks. However, long-term effects of high nitrate consumption remain unclear.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mention of vegetarians who consume higher nitrate levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary interventions involving green leafy vegetables, as a source of inorganic nitrate, could increase nitric oxide bioavailability and improve cardiovascular outcomes.
results_summary: Some studies reported positive effects on systolic blood pressure and endothelial function in hypertensive and chronic heart failure patients, but results were inconsistent, with declining effects in older individuals. More large-scale studies are needed to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertension, chronic heart failure, and potentially other cardiovascular disorders (though data is limited for diabetes, CHD, and chronic kidney failure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the associations between serum folate/folic acid levels and various diseases, focusing on the benefits and contradictions of folic acid supplementation.
results_summary: The study confirmed the benefit of folic acid supplementation in preventing neural tube defects (NTDs) during the pre-conception period but found mixed and unclear results regarding its efficacy in treating other diseases.
population_specificity: Women with previous pregnancies affected by NTDs and general populations with folate-related health concerns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a micronutrient-rich supplement containing green leafy vegetables, fruit, and milk affected fetal growth during pregnancy compared to a lower-micronutrient control snack.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of the micronutrient-rich supplement on fetal size or growth at any stage of pregnancy, though there were minor interactions between parity and allocation group for certain fetal measurements in the second trimester.
population_specificity: Non-pregnant women living in Mumbai slums, India, who were later followed through pregnancy (N = 6,513, with 1,677 fetuses analyzed).
effective_dosage: Daily micronutrient-rich snack (specific amounts not detailed).
study_duration: From before pregnancy until delivery (≥3 months before conception for a subset).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to re-evaluate the physiological role of inorganic nitrate from green leafy vegetables, focusing on its potential benefits in metabolic diseases like obesity and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that nitrate from green leafy vegetables may improve NO bioavailability, offering anti-obesity, anti-diabetic, and vascular benefits, countering previous concerns about toxicity.
population_specificity: General population, with implications for those with obesity, type 2 diabetes, and metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the interaction between dietary vitamin K intake (from green leafy vegetables) and the anticoagulant effect of vitamin K antagonists (VKAs).
results_summary: The study found conflicting evidence on the effect of dietary vitamin K on coagulation response, with some studies showing a negative correlation with INR changes, while others suggested a minimum intake is necessary for stable anticoagulation. High vitamin K intake (>150 μg/day) may affect coagulation, but restricting dietary vitamin K does not improve anticoagulation quality.
population_specificity: Patients on VKAs therapy for conditions like atrial fibrillation, prosthetic heart valves, and venous thromboembolism.
effective_dosage: Median dietary intake of vitamin K1 ranged from 76 to 217 μg/day.
interactions: Vitamin K-rich foods (e.g., green leafy vegetables) may interact with vitamin K antagonists (VKAs), but stable dietary habits are recommended over restriction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of folate, particularly from green leafy vegetables, in pregnancy and its role in preventing neural tube defects and other health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that green leafy vegetables are a significant natural source of folate, which is crucial for preventing neural tube defects, preterm delivery, and low birth weight. Folate bioavailability varies by food preparation and source, with green leafy vegetables being a key contributor.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and general population groups, with specific caution noted for the elderly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence for inorganic nitrate from green leafy vegetables and beetroot in enhancing sports and exercise performance.
results_summary: Dietary nitrate supplementation increases plasma nitrite concentration, reduces resting blood pressure, lowers the oxygen cost of submaximal exercise, and can enhance exercise tolerance and performance. The mechanisms behind these effects were also reviewed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of evidence, likely including athletes and healthy individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether supplementation with Green Oat Extract (GOE) could enhance wellness and wellbeing during smoking reduction or cessation by mitigating withdrawal symptoms and improving quality of life.
results_summary: GOE supplementation led to greater improvements in quality of life, stress reduction, and sleep quality compared to placebo. It also resulted in a higher percentage of successful smoking reducers (66.7% vs. 49.3%) and sustained improvements post-intervention.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing smoking reduction or cessation efforts.

study_goal: To determine whether regular daily consumption of wild green oat extract (WGOE) improves vasodilator function in systemic and cerebral arteries in healthy older adults.
results_summary: WGOE supplementation significantly increased both cerebral vasodilator responsiveness (CVR) and flow-mediated dilatation (FMD) by 42% and 41%, respectively, compared to placebo, with no changes in resting blood pressure. The improvements were well-tolerated and not correlated.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (>60 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic daily supplementation with wild green oat extract (WGOE) would result in sustained cognitive improvements in older adults.
results_summary: Chronic WGOE supplementation (1500 mg/day) did not affect any measures of cognition in healthy older adults, suggesting that the acute cognitive benefits observed in preliminary evaluations do not persist with long-term use. The study concluded that sustained effects might be more evident in individuals with mild cognitive impairment.
population_specificity: 37 healthy adults aged 67 ± 0.8 years (mean ± SEM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if green tea extract combined with a starch-rich meal could lower postprandial glucose and insulin levels in the morning and evening.
results_summary: Green tea extract did not significantly alter glucose or insulin iAUC but decreased peak insulin levels 30 minutes after the morning meal, indicating a time-of-day dependent effect on insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: Fourteen healthy adults
study_duration: Single meal intervention with measurements over 180 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antioxidant effects of 3% green tea extract versus 25% bamboo salt on the push-out bond strength of AH Plus sealer after sodium hypochlorite irrigation in root canals.
results_summary: The study found that 3% green tea extract significantly improved the push-out bond strength of AH Plus sealer compared to 25% bamboo salt after sodium hypochlorite irrigation, demonstrating its superior antioxidant effect in this context.
population_specificity: Single-rooted mandibular premolars (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 3% green tea extract solution (used as an irrigant).
study_duration: Not specified (single application during root canal treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of different blue light intensities during spreading on the formation of green tea aroma and volatile compounds.
results_summary: The study found that middle-intensity blue light (150 μmol/(m2∙s)) was most effective in developing a fruity and floral scent in green tea, compared to high- and low-intensity blue light. A total of 116 volatile compounds were detected, with alcohols being the most abundant.
population_specificity: Green tea samples treated under different blue light conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an integrated shaking and piling process could improve the flavor profile of summer green tea by reducing bitterness and astringency while enhancing sweetness and color.
results_summary: The treatment significantly improved sweet and kokumi flavors while reducing umami, astringency, and bitterness. It also enhanced yellowness and color saturation, linked to changes in non-volatile metabolites such as increased sweet-tasting amino acids and decreased bitter compounds.
population_specificity: Summer green tea (not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms by which Green Tea may mitigate the twelve hallmarks of aging and its potential as a geroscience intervention.
results_summary: The study found that Green Tea polyphenols enhance DNA repair, preserve telomere length, modulate epigenetic markers, improve proteostasis, regulate nutrient-sensing networks, and rejuvenate mitochondrial function. Additionally, it exhibits anti-inflammatory properties and may improve cognitive function, cardiovascular health, muscle preservation, and metabolic regulation in aging populations.
population_specificity: Aging populations (in vitro, animal, and human studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore green tea's potential in managing periodontal disease by examining its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial properties.
results_summary: Green tea, particularly its bioactive component EGCG, improved periodontal health by reducing pocket depth, inflammation, and bleeding. It showed moderate efficacy as an adjunct to conventional therapies and a natural alternative to chemical agents like chlorhexidine.
population_specificity: Individuals with periodontal disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects and mechanisms of Forsythia suspensa leaf green tea extract (STW) in treating COPD.
results_summary: STW reduced inflammation and oxidative stress in COPD mice, decreasing pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α, IL-8, IL-1β) and increasing antioxidant enzymes (SOD, catalase) in a dose-dependent manner. Network analysis identified 19 active components and 81 potential targets, suggesting multi-pathway involvement in alleviating pulmonary inflammation.
population_specificity: COPD-induced mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) preconditioned with green tea epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG) and miR-92a exhibit superior therapeutic effects in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) compared to unconditioned ADSCs.
results_summary: Preconditioning ADSCs with EGCG and miR-92a enhanced their viability via the CXCR4/p-Akt pathway and significantly improved RA symptoms in rats, including reducing joint pathologies and modulating the KLF4/IL-17/MMP-2 axis. Unconditioned ADSCs showed modest improvements, while EGCG- and miR-92a-preconditioned ADSCs demonstrated stronger therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with collagen-induced arthritis (CIA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of varying dietary green tea extract (GTE) levels on growth performance, Clostridium perfringens colonization, and inflammatory responses in broiler chickens during subclinical necrotic enteritis.
results_summary: GTE-supplemented diets mitigated growth depression during SNE, reduced intestinal CP infection, and modulated inflammatory responses in broiler chicks. Challenged chicks showed poorer growth and higher CP levels, but GTE supplementation improved outcomes.
population_specificity: One-day-old male broiler (Ross 708) chicks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether green tea consumption before, during, or after ovarian cancer treatment was associated with improved treatment response or survival outcomes.
results_summary: No association was found between green tea consumption during chemotherapy and treatment response. However, pre-diagnosis or post-treatment green tea consumption (≥1 cup/day) was weakly associated with improved overall survival but not progression-free survival. Herbal tea post-treatment showed improved progression-free survival but not overall survival.
